update.description:
Initial layout for the `ign` command line tool.

`ign` accepts multiple commands. Each command is implemented in a plugin that belongs to a specific Ignition project. For example, all the commands that start with `ign topic ...` will be handled by the Ignition Transport library.

Each Ignition library installs a YAML configuration file with the list of commands that provides, as well as a description of each command. Also, the configuration file contains the name of the library and some extra information. You can see an example [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/raw/ign_tool/conf/transport.yaml).

`ign` should work when a new Ignition library is installed/removed/updated.

`ign` loads all the Ignition configuration files and is able to display the list of available commands to the user. If the user types a valid command, `ign` will forward the arguments to the appropriate Ignition library, that will do the work.

`ign` is Ruby!

You can try this pull request with [pull_request_#36](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-request/36/) in `Ignition-transport` (implements `topic list` and `service list`).
update.title: ign tool infrastructure

content.raw:
Thanks, merged!

If for some reason the users install the Ignition libraries in a different place than `ign-tool`, the trick won't work but I guess we are covering the most common situation and we always have the environment variable as a backup plan.
content.html:
Thanks, merged!

If for some reason the users install the Ignition libraries in a different place than ign-tool, the trick won't work but I guess we are covering the most common situation and we always have the environment variable as a backup plan.

content.raw: Good point. We are choosing between two hardcoded variables. The `CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX` feels a bit better, and it will mean developers won't have to use the environment variable when installing localling. Check out the `ign_ruby_nate` branch.
content.html: Good point. We are choosing between two hardcoded variables. The CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX feels a bit better, and it will mean developers won't have to use the environment variable when installing localling. Check out the ign_ruby_nate branch.

update.title: ign tool infrastructure

content.raw:
This is the directory where the other Ignition libraries will put their configuration files. Not sure if we can assume that this directory will be the same than the `install prefix` used in this package.

E.g.: I install all the Ignition libraries using the debs, and then, I install this package without debs in ~/local.
content.html:
This is the directory where the other Ignition libraries will put their configuration files. Not sure if we can assume that this directory will be the same than the install prefix used in this package.

E.g.: I install all the Ignition libraries using the debs, and then, I install this package without debs in ~/local.

content.raw: We could parse this file using cmake, and substitute `/usr/share/ignition` with the specified install prefix.
content.html: We could parse this file using cmake, and substitute /usr/share/ignition with the specified install prefix.

content.raw:
Can you make the ign tool ignore files that are not in the yaml format? For exampl the ign tool produces an error if there is an empty `.yaml` file or a `.yaml` file with meaningless characters.


```
#!ruby

/home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign:54:in `block in <main>': undefined method `key?' for "asldfjls":String (NoMethodError)
	from /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign:47:in `glob'
	from /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign:47:in `<main>'
```
content.html:
Can you make the ign tool ignore files that are not in the yaml format? For exampl the ign tool produces an error if there is an empty .yaml file or a .yaml file with meaningless characters.

/home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign:54:in `block in <main>': undefined method `key?' for "asldfjls":String (NoMethodError)
    from /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign:47:in `glob'
    from /home/nkoenig/local/bin/ign:47:in `<main>'

content.raw:
I've fixed this. Now we support different versions installed in parallel. Each command has two new available options:

```
#!python
--force-version <VERSION>  Use a specific library version.
--versions                 Show the available versions.
```
content.html:
I've fixed this. Now we support different versions installed in parallel. Each command has two new available options:

--force-version <VERSION>  Use a specific library version.
--versions                 Show the available versions.

update.title: ign tool infrastructure

content.raw: While parsing all the the configuration files, `ign` checks that the commands provided by the libraries are not already announced by other library before. Assuming that we had two versions of the same library installed providing the same command line commands, we will get a `configuration error`.
content.html: While parsing all the the configuration files, ign checks that the commands provided by the libraries are not already announced by other library before. Assuming that we had two versions of the same library installed providing the same command line commands, we will get a configuration error.

content.raw: What are your thoughts on configuration file versioning? For example, let's say you have `ign-transport1` and `ign-transport2` installed. Can their config files live side-by-side, and which config file would be used by the `ign` tool?
content.html: What are your thoughts on configuration file versioning? For example, let's say you have ign-transport1 and ign-transport2 installed. Can their config files live side-by-side, and which config file would be used by the ign tool?
